results.name: Rank array R of 3/2 read by antidiagonals; this array is the dispersion of the complement of the sequence given by r(n) = r(n-1) + 1 + floor(3n/2) for n>=1, with r(0) = 1; that is, A077043(n+1).
comment: The sequence is a permutation of the positive integers and the array is a transposable dispersion.
Let T(n,k) be the rectangular version of the array at A036561, with northwest corner as shown here:
Then R(n,k) is the rank of T(n,k) when all the numbers in {T(n,k}} are jointly ranked. - _Clark Kimberling_, Jan 25 2018
link: Clark Kimberling and John E. Brown, Partial Complements and Transposable Dispersions, J. Integer Seqs., Vol. 7, 2004.
example: Let t=3/2; then R(i,j) = rank of (j,i) when all nonnegative integer pairs (a,b) are ranked by the relation << defined as follows: (a,b) << (c,d) if a + b*t < c + d*t, and also (a,b) << (c,d) if a + b*t = c + d*t and b < d.  Thus R(2,1) = 10 is the rank of (1,2) in the list (0,0) << (1,0) << (0,1) << (2,0) << (1,1) << (3,0) << (0,2) << (2,1) << (4,0) << (1,2).
mathematica: r = 20; r1 = 12;(*r=# rows of T,r1=# rows to show*);
c = 20; c1 = 12;(*c=# cols of T,c1=# cols to show*);
v = Complement[Range[Max[u]], u]; f[n_] := v[[n]]; Table[f[n], {n, 1, 30}]

mex[list_] := NestWhile[#1 + 1 &, 1, Union[list][[#1]] <= #1 &, 1,   Length[Union[list]]]; rows = {NestList[f, 1, c]}; Do[rows = Append[rows, NestList[f, mex[Flatten[rows]], r]], {r}]; w[i_, j_] := rows[[i, j]];
Flatten[Table[w[k, n - k + 1], {n, 1, c1}, {k, 1, n}]] (* A087465 sequence *)
TableForm[Table[w[i, 1] + w[1, j] + (i - 1)*(j - 1) - 1, {i, 1, 10}, {j, 1, 10}]] (* A087465 array, by formula *)
